title: Research
text:
Working Papers

The Not So Quiet Revolution: Signal and Noise in Central Bank Communication (2025)
with Leonardo Nogueira Ferreira, Caio Garzeri, Antônio Lima, and Victor Monteiro
Central Bank of Brazil — Working Paper Series No. 635
PDF


Abstract

We study central bank communication under heightened uncertainty and decompose official statements into informative signal and uninformative noise. The analysis highlights implications for expectation formation and the predictability of policy decisions.




An Organizational Structure Approach to Price Setting and Monetary Policy (2025)
with Victor Monteiro
Central Bank of Brazil — Working Paper Series No. 638
PDF


Abstract

We develop a New Keynesian framework in which price rigidity arises endogenously from organizational structure and incentive misalignment within firms. The model generates novel implications for inflation dynamics and monetary policy transmission.




Following the Informational Footsteps of the Supply Chain Tracks (2025)
with Victor Monteiro and Thiago Christiano Silva
Central Bank of Brazil — Working Paper Series No. 640
PDF


Abstract

We study information propagation in production networks using a model with incomplete information at the firm level. The framework links network structure, information frictions, and aggregate shock transmission, with supporting evidence from Brazilian firm-to-firm data.




Local Government Spending and Employment: Regression Discontinuity Evidence from Brazil (2017)
with Breno Braga and Benjamin Thompson
Working Paper
SSRN


Abstract

Using regression discontinuity designs, we estimate the causal effects of local government spending on employment outcomes in Brazil.




Optimal Policy with Liquidity Frictions (2014)
with Wei Cui
Working Paper
SSRN


Abstract

This paper studies optimal monetary policy in environments with liquidity frictions, highlighting trade-offs between macroeconomic stabilization and efficiency.

Publisher


Abstract

This chapter provides a comprehensive account of Brazil’s monetary and fiscal history from 1960 to 2016, emphasizing regime changes, institutional developments, and the interaction between fiscal and monetary policy.

title: Home
text:
Economist · Former Deputy Governor, Banco Central do Brasil · Visiting Scholar, Stanford University

My research focuses on monetary policy, expectations, and macro-financial linkages, with an emphasis on how policy design and communication affect economic outcomes. My work combines theory, empirical analysis, and policy applications, often drawing on Brazilian and international data.
Before joining Stanford, I served as Deputy Governor at the Central Bank of Brazil, where I was responsible for monetary policy and economic research.
Research interests - Monetary policy and inflation targeting
- Expectations, beliefs, and information frictions
- Macro-finance and financial intermediation
- Policy design and credibility
